title: Nick Kyrgios eats fan's chips in Indian Wells doubles exit
title_page: Nick Kyrgios eats fan's chips in Indian Wells doubles exit | Daily Mail Online
text:
He has caused controversy on the court with his previous misdemeanours, but Nick Kyrgios showed his cheekier side despite his Indian Wells doubles exit on Wednesday, taking a chip from a front-row fan.
The Australian has had to confront criticism of his on-court behaviour towards opponents and umpires in the past, but having reached the quarter-finals of the men's singles in California, he could afford to dabble in an act of devilment.
The outspoken Canberran was already trailing in his doubles match against Marcelo Melo and Lukasz Kubot when he could not resist the smell of french fries emanating from the front row seats.
Nick Kyrgios pinches a cheeky chip or two from the unexpectant front-row fan at Indian Wells
As partner Nenad Zimonjic ties his shoes, Kyrgios seizes his moment to refuel courtside
Kyrgios took drastic measures to change his fortunes with him already losing the match
The Australian returns to the court having taken another mouthful of chips
Not being able to resist the smell of fries like...�� @NickKyrgios #BNPPO17 pic.twitter.com/xDMzsL67zF — Tennis TV (@TennisTV) March 16, 2017
Partner Nenad Zimonjic was happy to use the pause in play to tie his shoelaces in between service games, but Kyrgios had other ideas.
Without a second thought, the 21-year-old delighted the sparsely populated court by approaching the man owning the bucket with one of his towels used as a bargaining 'chip'.
Not once, but twice does the affable rogue plunge his fingers into the man's fries dish, and a straight-faced Kyrgios even dunks his final chip in sauce before wiping his fingers and returning to the court.
The Canberran still likes to show his personality on court despite a more mellowed approach
Kyrgios has enjoyed a fine start to the 2017 season and is aiming to reach another semi-final
The 21-year-old will now face Roger Federer for a place in the semi-finals of the singles event
The Australian shocked Novak Djokovic to set up a clash with Roger Federer on Friday - winning his fourth-round match 6-4, 7-6 (7-3) - but he was unable to carry on his good form as a wildcard entry in the doubles alongside Zimonjic, as he went down 6-1 6-3 in California.
Kyrgios, who is looking to reach his third straight semi-final of the season in Indian Wells, will not be indulging too much in fatty foods ahead of his second battle with the 35-year-old Federer.
The pair have only faced each other once before, with the Australian winning 6-7 7-6 7-6 in the second round of the Madrid Masters in 2015.
Should he prevail once more against the Swiss, Kyrgios would face the winner of Jack Sock's game with Kei Nishikori in the last four.
